BE101.name: Introduction to Biosystems Engineering
BE101.description: Introduction to the profession of biosystems engineering. Case studies of engineering design problems with a biological component. Exploration of career opportunities and ethical framework for the profession.
BE101.prerequisite: (MTH 116 or concurrently) or (MTH 132 or concurrently) or (MTH 152H or concurrently) or (LB 118 or concurrently)

BE230.name: Engineering Analysis of Biological Systems
BE230.description: Biosystems modeling of growth and dynamic interactions. Conservation of mass, and sustainability. Steady-state and stability analysis. Ecological concepts. Life-cycle analysis. Design for environment.
BE230.prerequisite: (MTH 132 or MTH 152H or LB 118) and ((BS 162 or concurrently) or (BS 182H or concurrently) or (LB 144 or concurrently)) and (EGR 102 or concurrently)

BE332.name: Engineering Properties of Biological Materials
BE332.description: Physical and thermal properties of biological materials necessary for the design and analysis of processes and equipment in biosystems.
BE332.prerequisite: (BE 101 or concurrently) and (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and CE 221
BE332.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Biosystems and Agricultural Engineering.

BE334.name: Biosystems Engineering Laboratory Practice
BE334.description: Sensors and instrumentation for measuring and analyzing properties of biological materials and systems.
BE334.prerequisite: (BE 101 or concurrently) and (BS 171 or BS 172) and PHY 184
BE334.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Biosystems and Agricultural Engineering.

BE350.name: Heat and Mass Transfer in Biosystems
BE350.description: Steady state and transient heat conduction. Radiation and convection heat transfer. Heat exchangers. Mass transfer application problems in biosystems engineering.
BE350.prerequisite: (BE 101 or concurrently) and (MTH 235 or LB 220) and ((CE 321 or concurrently) or (CHE 311 or concurrently) or (ME 332 or concurrently)) and ((CEM 143 or concurrently) or (CEM 251 or concurrently) or (CEM 351 or concurrently))
BE350.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Engineering.

BE351.name: Thermodynamics for Biological Engineering
BE351.description: Thermodynamics of biological systems. First and second laws of thermodynamics. Power and refrigeration cycles. Water relations and psychrometry. Chemical and phase equilibria.
BE351.prerequisite: (BE 101 or concurrently) and (MTH 235 or MTH 255H or LB 220) and (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145)
BE351.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Engineering.

BE360.name: Microbial Systems Engineering
BE360.description: Application of engineering and biological principles to the analysis of microbial systems. Kinetic analyses and modeling of microbial growth, survival, and inactivation for engineering applications.
BE360.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Engineering.

BE385.name: Engineering Design and Optimization for Biological Systems
BE385.description: Design and optimization techniques applied to engineering problems with biological constraints. Project management. Engineering economics. Linear programming.
BE385.prerequisite: (BE 101 and (BE 230 or concurrently)) and (MTH 235 or MTH 255H or LB 220)
BE385.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Engineering.

BE402.name: Agricultural Climatology
BE402.description: Relationships between climate and agriculture in resource assessment, water budget analysis, meteorological hazards, pests, crop-yield modeling, and impacts of global climate change.
BE402.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

BE418.name: Animal Agriculture and the Environment
BE418.description: Comprehensive nutrient management plans (CNMP) for animal feeding operations. Trends in animal production, environmental issues, and diet formulation and their impact on manure production. Development of CNMP for a specific animal feeding operation.
BE418.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (CEM 143 or CEM 251)

BE419.name: Applications of Geographic Information Systems to Natural Resources Management
BE419.description: Application of geographic information systems, remote sensing, and global positioning systems to integrated planning and management for fish, wildlife, and related resources.

BE429.name: Fundamentals of Food Engineering
BE429.description: Definition and measurement of food properties, thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, and mass transfer.
BE429.prerequisite: (FSC 325) and (MTH 124 or MTH 132 or LB 118 or MTH 152H) and (PHY 231 or PHY 183 or PHY 193H or LB 273)
BE429.restrictions: Not open to students in the College of Engineering.

BE443.name: Restoration Ecology
BE443.description: Principles of ecological restoration of disturbed or damaged ecosystems. Design, implementation, and presentation of restoration plans. Field trips required.

BE444.name: Biosensors for Medical Diagnostics
BE444.description: Biosensors, their components, properties, and associated electronics for applications in medical diagnostics.
BE444.prerequisite: (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and (CEM 141 or CEM 151) and (ECE 302 or ECE 345 or BE 334 or CEM 333)
BE444.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Engineering.

BE449.name: Human Health Risk Analysis for Engineering Controls
BE449.description: Characterize human health risk from microbial stressors. Develop and evaluate engineering controls for risk management.
BE449.prerequisite: (BE 385 and BE 360 and BE 332) or (CE 371 and CE 372 and ENE 487)
BE449.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Engineering.

BE456.name: Electric Power and Control
BE456.description: Alternating current circuits, power distribution, electrical machines, protection, and programmable motor controllers. Design project related to food and agricultural industries.

BE461.name: Seminar in Plant, Animal and Microbial Biotechnology
BE461.description: Current applications of plant, animal and microbial biotechnology in agriculture and related industries. Technologies under development and factors associated with moving from laboratory to product development. Field trips required.
BE461.prerequisite: (ANS 425 or concurrently) or (BE 360 or concurrently) or (CSS 451 or concurrently) or (MMG 445 or concurrently)

BE467.name: BioEnergy Feedstock Production
BE467.description: Agronomic, economic, technological, and environmental principles involved in bioenergy feedstock production. Cultivation, harvest, transportation, and storage of agricultural and forest biomass.
BE467.prerequisite: MTH 103 or MTH 116 or MTH 124 or MTH 132 or LB 118 or MTH 152H or MTH 133 or MTH 153H or LB 119

BE468.name: Biomass Conversion Engineering
BE468.description: Physicochemical and biological pretreatment. Biomass conversion to alcohols, biodiesel, bio-oil, syngas, and other value-added products using advanced biological, chemical, and thermochemical treatments.

BE469.name: Sustainable Bioenergy Systems
BE469.description: Biorefinery analysis and system design. Life cycle assessment to evaluate sustainability of bioenergy systems. Current policy regulating the bioeconomy and system economics. Product commercialization.
BE469.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Engineering.

BE475.name: International Studies in Biosystems Engineering
BE475.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BE475.description: Study abroad emphasizing biosystems and agricultural engineering issues affecting agriculture and natural resources in world, national, and local communities.

BE477.name: Food Engineering: Fluids
BE477.description: Unit operations, process engineering, equipment, and industrial practices of the food industry. Manufactured dairy products

BE478.name: Food Engineering: Solids
BE478.description: Analysis and design of unit operations and complete systems for handling, processing, and manufacturing bulk, granular, and solid food products. Material variability and microbial, chemical, and physical hazards.

BE481.name: Water Resources Systems Analysis and Modeling
BE481.description: Hydrology of natural systems. Quantifying runoff, infiltration, and evapotranspiration. Geospatial data collection at watershed scale. Geographical information system application in hydrology and ecosystems engineering. Watershed modeling and applications in engineering design and decision-making.
BE481.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Engineering.

BE482.name: Engineering Ecological Treatment Systems
BE482.description: Analysis of pollutants in ecological systems. Engineering design of ecological systems to prevent, mitigate, and treat diffuse and point source pollution, including low impact development (LID) strategies and best management practices (BMPs).
BE482.prerequisite: (BE 350 or ENE 483 or CHE 312) and (BE 360 or ENE 487 or CHE 431)
BE482.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Engineering.

BE484.name: Water Resource Recovery Engineering
BE484.description: Municipal, industrial, and rural wastewater characteristics. Selection of best site- and management-specific treatment strategy, including the influence of governmental policy and societal needs.
BE484.prerequisite: BE 360 or (ENE 487 or concurrently) or approval of department
BE484.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Engineering.

BE485.name: Biosystems Design Techniques
BE485.description: Engineering design process. Problem identification, analysis, design, modeling, materials, cost estimation, and final specifications. Safety, environmental, and ethical considerations.
BE485.prerequisite: BE 332 and BE 334 and BE 350 and BE 351 and BE 360 and BE 385 or approval of department
BE485.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Biosystems Engineering major.

BE487.name: Biosystems Design Project (W)
BE487.description: Individual or team design project selected in BE 485. Information expansion, development of alternatives, and evaluation, selection, and completion of a design project.
BE487.prerequisite: (BE 485) and completion of Tier I Writing requirement
BE487.restrictions: Open to seniors in Biosystems Engineering major.

BE490.name: Independent Study
BE490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BE490.description: Supervised individual student research and study in biosystems engineering.

BE491.name: Special Topics in Biosystems Engineering
BE491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

BE815.name: Experimentation and Instrumentation in Biosystems Engineering
BE815.description: Establish generalized experimental study planning, measurement, data collection and execution skills, which are applicable to individual topics/projects/areas in biological systems.
BE815.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Engineering.

BE820.name: Research Methods in Biosystems Engineering
BE820.description: Procedures and methods for designing and executing research projects.
BE820.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or College of Engineering.

BE835.name: Modeling Methods in Biosystems Engineering
BE835.description: Establish generalized model planning and execution skills, which is applicable to individual topics/projects/areas in biological systems.
BE835.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Engineering.

BE844.name: Biosensor Principles and Applications
BE844.description: Nanotechnology-based biosensors, their components, desirable properties, and associated electronics. Applications related to healthcare, biodefense, food and water safety, agriculture, bio-production, and environment. Multidisciplinary interactions necessary for biosensor development.

BE846.name: Integrated Climate and Cropping System Modeling
BE846.description: Crop simulation modeling for water and nutrient use under resource limitations and varying climatic conditions.

BE849.name: Microbial Risk Modeling and Analysis
BE849.description: Characterization, analysis, and modeling of human health risk from exposures to microbial contaminants. Applications in food safety, water quality, public health and environmental science and policy.

BE869.name: Life Cycle Assessment for Bioenergy and Bioproduct Systems
BE869.description: Life cycle assessment to evaluate the environmental impacts of biological and chemical conversion processes. Biomass supply chain economics and technoeconomics for biomass conversion. Current policy considerations impacting the adoption of bioenergy and bioproduct systems.
BE869.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the Department of Biosystems and Agricultural Engineering or approval of department.

BE881.name: Ecohydrology
BE881.description: Identify and quantify the critical linkages between ecological processes and the hydrological cycle.

BE882.name: Advanced Topics in Ecological Engineering
BE882.description: Rural and suburban water quality challenges. Science and design of rural and suburban water treatment and resource recovery systems.

BE890.name: Special Problems
BE890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

BE891.name: Advanced Topics in Biosystems Engineering
BE891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BE891.description: Biosystems engineering topics not covered in regular courses.
BE891.restrictions: Open only to seniors and graduate students.

BE892.name: Biosystems Engineering Seminar
BE892.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or College of Engineering.

BE899.name: Master's Thesis Research
BE899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BE899.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the Biosystems Engineering major.

BE999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
BE999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BE999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Biosystems Engineering Major.
